passage:
The top of a tectonic plate is made of crust. There are two types of crust: oceanic and continental.
Oceanic crust is denser than continental crust.
Continental crust is thicker than oceanic crust.

question.prompt: Why are oceanic plates submerged in water while continental plates are not?
answers: Ocean crust is denser and, therefore, thinner than continental crust, allowing water to fill the difference.
Continental crust experiences more volcanic flow, allowing it to build taller despite the weight of its rock base.
Oceanic crust is the real crust, while all continental crust is built up on an oceanic crust base.
Continental crust is less dense, so it can float on a thick layer of water beneath it while oceanic crust is denser, so it sinks no matter how much water is beneath it.

passage:
Oceanic and continental crust have very different compositions.
Oceanic crust is largely made up of igneous rocks like basalt.
Continental crust is largely made up of granite.

question.prompt: From the composition of continental and oceanic plates, what can we conclude about granite vs. basalt (a type of igneous rock)?
answers: Basalt is denser than granite
Basalt is heavier than granite
Granite is rarer than basalt
Granite is denser than basalt

passage:
There are three kinds of plate boundaries: convergent, divergent, and transform. Convergent and divergent boundaries are like opposites.
In a divergent boundary, two plates move apart. Rifts and ridges are common at these boundaries.
In a transform boundary, two plates slide past each other.
Earthquakes are common at transform boundaries.

question.prompt: What kind of fault is the San Andreas Fault in California?
answers: Convergent
Divergent
Transform
Metamorphic

passage:
Oceanic-oceanic convergence is where two plates made of oceanic crust converge. One plate subducts under the other, forming trenches and underwater volcanoes.
Continental-continental convergence occurs where two continental plates converge. One plate subducts, melts and becomes part of the mantle, while the other compacts and builds up.

question.prompt: What would you expect to form at a Continental-continental convergent boundary?
answers: Mountains
A trench
Volcanoes
Both A and B

passage:
Oceanic-continental convergence occurs where an oceanic plate converges with a continental plate. The oceanic plate subducts under the continental plate because it’s denser.
Oceanic-continental convergences share features with oceanic-oceanic convergences.

question.prompt: Several large and active volcanoes are located near the Indonesian islands. What kind of plate boundary do these islands most likely sit on?
answers: Transform
Subduction
Convergent
Divergent

passage:
Sea floor spreading is the creation of new crust or lithosphere at a divergent plate boundary.
Most divergent plate boundaries occur between oceanic plates.
As plates drift apart, magma rises through the boundary to create new crust.

question.prompt: Based on plate tectonic theory, why is there not much lava on land?
answers: Lava only comes from active volcanoes, and most volcanoes are underwater.
Lava cools quickly on the surface, so we don’t see much of it.
Lava most easily comes from divergent plate boundaries and most divergent boundaries are underwater.
Lava can melt the thinner oceanic crust more easily than the thick continental crust, so it can escape into the ocean easier than it can on land.

passage:
As the sea floor spreads, new crust is continually made at the boundary as long as the plates move apart.
Older crust is found far away from the boundary and new crust is found close to the boundary.
Ridges created by sea floor spreading move as quickly as 12 cm per year.

question.prompt: As the sea floor spreads, more ocean crust is created. Will this greatly affect the land-to-sea ratio?
answers: Yes, ocean crust will keep spreading while land is fixed, so one day the oceans will spread onto continental plates.
No, new ocean crust is created, but continental-oceanic subduction zones allow new land to be made from volcanic material.
Yes, Earth used to be almost all land, but sea floor spreading has reduced the land to less than 1/3 of the Earth’s surface.
No, new ocean crust is created, but old ocean crust piles higher until it becomes continental crust, making more land.

passage:
Rock in the mantle is not molten or liquid but a plastic-like fluid. Because it is fluid, it is able to transfer heat through convection.
Convection is the transfer of heat from one place to another by movement of a fluid.
The fluid carries thermal energy with it. The movement creates a circulation motion of warm and cold fluid.

question.prompt: Why does the Earth’s mantle move?
answers: The Earth’s motion around the sun causes the fluid mantle to shift around
The tectonic events like earthquakes or volcanic eruptions cause the mantle to shift around.
The Earth’s iron core generates a magnetic field that causes charged particles in the mantle to move.
The difference in temperature between the Earth’s core and crust causes hotter mantle to rise and cool, and colder mantle to fall and heat in a cycle that moves mantle.

passage:
Scientists believe convection in the asthenosphere causes tectonic plates to move.
When mantle spreads along the top of the asthenosphere, it transfers heat to the lithosphere.
More importantly, the moving mantle “pulls” lithosphere with it. This pull is believed to drive the motion of tectonic plates.

question.prompt: Given that the Moon’s interior is much colder and lighter than Earth’s, how much tectonic activity should we expect on the Moon in comparison to Earth?
answers: More, the Moon is lighter so the plates on the moon can move more easily.
Less, the Moon has less convection to move its plates because its core is colder.
More, the Moon’s surface-core temperature difference is greater, making convection more powerful.
Less, the Moon’s core is lighter which means there is a smaller magnetic field that leads to less mantle movement.

passage:
The Continental Drift Theory is a scientific theory that explains the movement of tectonic plates and continents. According to this theory, continents slowly drift (a few centimeters a year) along with their tectonic plates.
Today, North and South America are moving westward, while Australia is moving to the north.

question.prompt: According to Continental Drift Theory, the continents are slowly moving. In 150 million years, what could we expect Earth’s continents to look like?
answers: Australia collides with southeast Asia, North and South America detach, Africa drifts south.
Australia drifts east into the middle of the Pacific, Africa collides with India, North and South America combine, filling in the Gulf of Mexico.
Australia collides with southeast Asia, North and South America drift west towards Asia, Africa drifts north, filling the Mediterranean.
The continents look similarly to how they are today, but a few centimeters shifted.

passage:
One of the main roles of the female reproductive system is to produce eggs.
Eggs are female gametes (sex cells) and are made in the ovaries.
Eggs are made in the body before birth by meiosis, but they do not fully develop until later in life. Eggs are released from the ovaries during ovulation into the fallopian tubes.

question.prompt: What role do the ovaries play in human reproduction?
answers: Housing fertilized eggs
Releasing unfertilized eggs to be fertilized
Creating eggs regularly throughout a female’s life
Providing pleasurable stimulation during sex

passage:
The Fallopian tubes are the tubes that stretch from the uterus to the ovaries.
During ovulation, an egg is released from the ovaries into the Fallopian tube.
After successful fertilizing sex, the fertilized egg travels from the Fallopian tube into the uterus.

question.prompt: Where does sperm usually meet with an unfertilized egg?
answers: The vagina
The uterus
The Fallopian tube
The ovary

passage:
The hymen is a thin piece of mucosal tissue that surrounds or partially covers the external vaginal opening.
Most hymens contain some small perforations by puberty, allowing menstrual fluids to pass through the hymen.
Hymens can rip or tear from many forms of physical trauma to the region.

question.prompt: Is the state of the hymen a reliable indicator of virginity?
answers: Yes, because the hymen is ripped or torn during penetrative sex, we can use its state to determine virginity.
No, because the hymen can repair itself, we cannot use it as a reliable indicator of virginity.
Yes, any action that causes the hymen to rip or tear can be considered sex, so the hymen’s state is a reliable indicator of virginity.
No, because the hymen tears can have numerous origins, the hymen is not a reliable indicator of virginity.

passage:
Estrogen is the main sex hormone in females.
Estrogen has two major roles in the reproductive system. First, in teenage years, it promotes the development of female sex organs and other common female physical traits.
Additionally, estrogen is needed for a woman to release eggs.

question.prompt: When in a typical menstrual cycle are estrogen levels at their highest?
answers: Shortly before ovulation
Shortly before a period
Immediately after ovulation ends
Immediately after a period ends

passage:
A typical menstrual cycle lasts about 28 days.
In the first 7 days, a period occurs when the walls of the uterus thin.
In the next week, the uterine walls build up and become thicker.
On day 14 or 15 an egg is released by the ovaries.
Until day 28, the uterine walls continue to grow thicker and spongier.

question.prompt: Why does the uterus build its walls during a typical menstrual cycle?
answers: To allow new uterine skin to be shed during a period
To protect from an infection during sex
To prepare the uterus to accept a fertilized egg
None of the above

passage:
Once ovulation occurs, the follicle that contained the egg transforms into something called a corpus luteum and begins to produce progesterone, a secondary sex hormone, as well as estrogen.
Progesterone levels peak about halfway through this phase.
The hormonal changes of the luteal phase are associated with common premenstrual symptoms that many people experience, such as mood changes, headaches, acne, bloating, and breast tenderness.

question.prompt: If an egg is fertilized during ovulation, can typical premenstrual symptoms still be experienced?
answers: No, periods cannot occur during pregnancy, so premenstrual symptoms are no longer experienced once an egg is fertilized.
Yes, many premenstrual symptoms are the same as pregnancy symptoms.
No, a fertilized egg blocks signals to create progesterone, so no premenstrual symptoms are experienced.
Yes, progesterone is still created by the corpus luteum so premenstrual symptoms are still experienced during the first weeks of pregnancy.

passage:
Both estrogen and testosterone are produced by ovaries.
Testosterone in females is released into the bloodstream in relatively small quantities.
High levels of testosterone are associated with increased body hair, acne, increased muscle mass, and deepening of voice.

question.prompt: What common physiological differences in males and females can be attributed to differences in testosterone levels?
answers: Deepness of voice, body hair quantity, muscle mass
Acne, deepness of voice, hip shape, growth of breasts
Muscle mass, height, sexual organs, body hair quantity
Possession of a Y-chromosome, muscle mass, intellect

passage:
Estrogen is produced in several ways in the human body.
In premenopausal women, the ovaries are the primary source of estrogen.
Other estrogen sources include the liver, adrenal glands, breasts, and body fat.

question.prompt: Why are female athletes at a higher risk of having low estrogen?
answers: Female athletes produce more testosterone than typical females, throwing off their hormone balance.
Female athletes have less body fat than typical females, so they produce less estrogen.
Female athletes take supplements to reduce estrogen production to aid in performance.
Female athletes exert too much effort, taxing their organs and glands, reducing their overall estrogen production.

passage:
Menopause is a time that marks the permanent end of menstruation in a female.
Menstruation is associated with infertility as well as a number of other symptoms.
The main cause of menopause is the aging and depletion of the finite number of eggs created at birth in the ovaries, though it can be accelerated by other factors.

question.prompt: Why do males not experience menopause or a menopause-like state?
answers: Males don’t have ovaries, so they lack the organ associated with menopause.
Males can’t become pregnant, so their infertility is less noticeable.
Males produce their gametes continuously throughout life, so they do not become infertile through deterioration of gametes in the same way females do.
Males do experience a menopause-like state because they lose testosterone as they age.

passage:
The last phase of a menstrual cycle is called the secretory phase.
In this phase, the uterine lining secretes chemicals that either support pregnancy if there is a fertilized egg or prepares the walls to break down if no egg was fertilized.
Chemicals called prostaglandins help breakdown of the uterine wall by causing the uterine muscle to contract.

question.prompt: What happens if an egg is fertilized that prevents the uterine walls from breaking down again?
answers: Prostaglandin production is inhibited, reducing the breakdown of uterine walls.
Estrogen production is boosted to promote wall development rather than breakdown.
The corpus luteum increases progesterone production, stopping wall breakdown.
The fertilized egg physically prevents the uterus from contracting, which keeps the walls from breaking down.
